title: Something in my PC first died, then I killed the PSU. A repair dwindle boogaloo. A man versus technology narration that will move all rationale you've got left into computer repair. A simple ... ;;; Perchance ;;;.
self_text: Hello Redditors! Very,  very  funny story happened today. Well, not for me, but that's not the point.     It had been a beautiful morning of Eight of November. A young, yet aspiring man hath riseth from his bed, waddled to his seat, and henceforth the story fully began. He awoke his computer from sleep as always, and frittered away the time. Seconds felt like pure blissful eons, as he scrolled through the endless internet. He decided to start a long dead game called Evolve, and start it he did, indeed. 10 minutes into a thousandth match of his life, his PC  suddenly   shut down . This has happened before.     "A power outage it must've been!"  , - he thinks to himself. But, as swiftly as he came to that conclusion, he just as quickly noticed the contradiction in front of him, as well as above him. Ceiling lights remained on, and router remained on as well. By this time - the computer has already started turning itself back on. He waits 15 seconds for the splash image to arrive - but it never does. So, he resets the computer. Still nothing.  Coincidentally, he notices that the mouse and keyboard lights aren't coming on either, so he grabs his pluggable USB voltage meter and plugs it into his USB ports - it reads 3.5V. 1.5V lower than intended. Instantly, frightened of data loss, he turns off the computer and removes all drives. Then, he grabs his voltmeter and measures 12V, 5V and 3.3V rails of the PSU. He reads 9.5V, 3.5V and 2.7V. All lower. Not good. He thinks it's a bad PSU when he notices that his motherboard has LED debugging LEDs. He reads what the LED says - the "CPU FAULT" LED is on. What could it be?   The introduction has been pretty simple so far.   Sudden shutdown  Won't post, but fans spin  Low voltage on all rails, but...  IS IT?   the story continues     He decides to remove the GPU as well, to prevent the damage to it, as he remembers the GPU has very sensitive MOSFETs that operate in a specific voltage saturation region and low voltage could kill them. Besides, the computer has integrated graphics, so that's not a problem.     Correcting steps, commence!       With only PSU, Motherboard, RAM and CPU remaining in the case, he decides to clear the BIOS via BIOS jumper as well as remove the BIOS battery for 30 minutes. He does it, no change.    He decides to shuffle ram, no change.    Voltage gets measured again, and this time..  SURPRISE!  Voltages are good and within spec! 12V, 4.98V and 3.3V!    He decides to take out PSU completely and to the paperclip test - it works great! So..  is it not the psu after all?      What do we know so far?   Voltages seem to be fine now  Still no post  Paperclip PSU test works ok   What happened next?    Stupidest moment of the story begins!   Next loical step in diagnostic would be reseating the CPU, possibly a new one and trying a second motherboard. As motherboards are more expensive than cheapest compatible CPU, he decides to get a CPU. However, the seller said it will have to wait until tomorrow, so he grows impatient. He searches the internet a bit about the problem a Youtube video about an user facing the exact same issue and solving it! And the comment section is FULL or positive replies. So he decides to try it!      How is it done?   Simple, turn on your PC that won't post, and then quickly shift your ON/OFF switch on the PSU back and forth, quickly as in crazy fast.  I did that once, nothing happened. Second time, nothing. I guessed I was too slow. Third time I'll try it super fast, I thought to myself. So I do it and - woo! Power outage for real!! Wait - that's my breakers popping. Wait hold on did my PSU just blo-----.   Yes.    Yes it did.    So all in all my beloved Redditors, now I'm stuck with a dead PSU and either a dead motherboard or CPU. I'm out of ideas or any thoughts at all, so I hoped that you'd have something to share in the comments.     Thanks for reading, love you all.

title: Creating new Smart Home
self_text: Hi all!  In my previous apartment I had a really nice Home Assistant setup, but some time has passed since then and my conditions changed a lot, so I need some help to get me started.  In the old apartment I used Sonoff devices to control the lights and heating. For thermostats I used Mijia bluetooth devices and everything worked just great...  I currently have a couple of Nest Mini and Nest Hub devices that shall be used for voice control. I also have a Xiaomi desk lamp and a Roborock cleaning robot. I plan to display the Home Assistant dashboard on the Nest Hubs, but I am not sure how that actually works. I have seen the cast option, but still have 2 questions:   Is casting a 2 way control, or is it just for showing the dashboard?  Can I make the cast always available on the Hub, so that the user can switch between different things on the Hub?   Now I need a solution for my radiators. I have seen that the Bosch has released a new version of their Zigbee thermostats. I have shortly used them and they had a problem with overshooting the temperature a lot. I quess that they have fixed that by now with an update, but if I connect HA directly to thermostats without a bridge, I wouldn't get the updates. The other option would be to get Tado devices, which are not Zigbee, but I have seen that they should work with HomeKit in Home Assistant. I guess that Tado software is more mature than Bosch and has more functionality overall. Finally, I could get Aqara thermostats for almost the same money as Tado, but I was not really impressed with the build quality...   Is there any way to update the devices without a bridge and cloud, but directly via Zigbee for example?  Das Tado work locally with HA and HomeKit?  How does Tado integrate into HA?    I plan to automate lighting again, but this time probably with Shelly devices instead of Sonoff. I guess they are a fair bit better too...  Which Zigbee stick would you choose? ConBee II or Sonoff Plus?   Do you maybe have some other advice for me? What should I consider or take care about?  Thanks a lot!!! :)

title: Got malware after being dumb but removed it within minutes, am I safe?
self_text: So basically I was dumb and got malware from something I definitely should not have downloaded, but I picked up on it within minutes of infection and quickly scanned with Malwarebytes. It found 110 items, so I quickly quarantined and deleted them. Of course, it didn't come without complications, and over the last few days or so I've had multiple accounts attempted to be hacked. I made sure to change all passwords and have every single kind of protection on my accounts, and I've been vigilantly watching them to make sure I'm in the clear. Here's the thing though, while my computer is running pretty much as it should and I feel mostly safe, there's still something in the back of my mind that's telling me that it isn't safe, and I've noticed certain things like commands in Chrome take twice or three times to respond (Like CTRL + T and CTRL + W), and the fact that I've scanned with Malwarebytes in safe mode and it hasn't picked up on anything which makes me believe there's something still hiding somewhere. I've pretty much installed a good portion of the reputable antivirus programs out there (Bitdefender, Malwarebytes, Hitmanpro, etc.), none of which have picked up anything since the original infection, and I've even considered using Norton Power Eraser as well. I know a lot of you will say to just wipe and reinstall Windows, but it's incredibly time consuming and I'm not sure I'm able to currently.   Sorry if this is incredibly long, I'm just not sure what I should do going forward. Any advice is incredibly appreciated.

I found a psu that seemed to pass all the tests, yet every single b550 motherboard I research seems to have some problem. And its tricky too… I search amazon and go straight to the one star reviews. Filter out some more blatant DOA reviews. There was one board I had my eyes set on, the ASUS ROG Strix B550-A (also applies to F), and there is just a massive undiscussed issue with its ethernet ports apparently, they just dont work for many people. Every single board has this weird problem or multiple problems, and all I can think every single time is “wow, I would pay more so I can avoid that issue.” But while that may work for psu’s, it seems that the reviews play volleyball with the manufacturers— “never buying an msi product again. Plugged in x asus board and worked perfectly.” Reverse that on the asus product page.   I hate that uncertainty. Maybe Im just a baby though. What I suppose Im asking is, when it comes to b550’s, which is the best brand/model that can be proven (preferably through a reliable reviewing tech site)? Or is it not proven and just hearsay?

title: RTX 3060 display disconnecting
self_text: Hello,  I built my girlfriend a PC about a year ago, and I've just recently found out that since it was built, the display tends to cut out every hour or so.   Issue   About every hour, the display will turn black as if the cable was disconnected. The monitor will receive no signal for about 2-3 seconds and then it kicks back in. title: PC won't POST with CPU installed!
self_text: So, I have a PC that has been working fine for almost 2 years now. One fine day, I turn it on and nothing works. No power, nothing. I did notice the system time was incorrect the last time my PC booted up, so I was hoping that replacing the CMOS battery would work, but alas, clearing the CMOS and replacing the battery didn't help either.  ​  Obviously I had to strip everything and do breadboarding to check each component. I tried updating the BIOS using USB Flashback and that seemed to go through. Next, with nothing on the MoBo, I tried booting it up. It booted up fine, with the CPU Debug light on.  Now, when I install the CPU and try to turn on, nothing gives? No power, no debug LED, nothing!   I've also tried plugging everything back in to make sure it's not missing any component, but I still see no power. The only time there is any sign of life on the MoBo is when I take out the CPU.  ​  Do you reckon my CPU has died on me? Or is this a motherboard failure?   Thanks for any help!  ​  Specs:  Ryzen 5 5600X  RTX 3080  8x2 3200Mhz RAM  B550 Gaming Edge WiFi motherboard

title: 13 Pro Max vs. Samsung s20+

title: Seeking a consensus from everyone. I want everyone's opinions on a potential upgrade!
self_text: So I've tried doing my own research, and it just sends me down a huge rabbit hole of PCIe versions, bottleneck percentages, and cpu types until I feel like i am getting nowhere. So I turn to you wonderful folks at r/buildapc to get some advice. I generally find that en-mass consensus is more important and helpful than one or two people's opinions, so I'm looking for as many people as possible to respond!  ​  I'd like to do some upgrades to a gaming PC i built 6 years ago. I'm starting to notice that modern games are outstripping my PC's capabilities, so I'd like to get a meaningful boost  to FPS and load times and get another 5-7 years out of my current PC before a full rebuild. With a new baby on the way I'm trying to get some meaningful upgrades for not too much money. My current specs are as follows:  MOBO: Asus M5A97 R2.0 (2 PCIe 2.0 X16 slots)  CPU: AMD FX-8370 Eight-Core Processor, 4000 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 8 Logical Processor(s)  GPU: ZOTAC GTX 1070  RAM: 16GB DDR3  Keep in mind my monitor runs at 1440p and 60hz, so I'm not one of those types who NEEDS 120 fps to play. I'm happy at 60, so long as it stays relatively close to 60 throughout the experience. My most demanding games are things like Destiny 2, Racing Sims, and big Strategy Games with a lot on screen at once.  ​  I was thinking of putting in an NVMe M.2 SSD using a PCIe converter (my MOBO doesn't have an M.2 capable slot as is.)  Overclocking the CPU to 4.5 ghz, and a RTX 3070 Ti into the current MOBO, going for a load time reduction in the SSD and some extra GPU power to see me through the next 5-7 years or so. Is this a decent upgrade in everyone's opinion, or will I experience too much CPU bottleneck for this to be worthwhile? I feel like a 4.5ghz CPU should still be very fast, but I've heard that my particular brand of CPU isn't great, which leaves me worried the extra GPU money would be wasted without also buying a new CPU. I've tried to find out myself, but i feel get so much different information i get overwhelmed and can't figure out exactly what to do.   ​  So in the all-knowing opinion of build-a-pc, what do y'all think? Is this a worthwhile upgrade or not?

title: Should / How Do I Set Up One 4k Monitor With Two Secondary 1080p Monitors?
self_text: Hi! I'm preparing to build my first PC and my vision is to have a 32" 4K 240Hz monitor in the middle (Samsung Odyssey Neo G8) and have two 24" 1080p 60Hz monitors (Dell UltraSharp U2414H) oriented vertically, one on either side. The other relevant parts will  hopefully  be an i9 13900K CPU, an ASUS TUF GAMING 4090 GPU, and an ASUS ROG MAXIMUS Z790 HERO motherboard.  I have a couple questions about how this multi-monitor setup would work.   Question the first   What would happen if I ran all three monitors off the 4090 (4K via HDMI, 1080p's via DisplayPort)?  Say I'm playing a game on the 4K monitor. Would I get higher FPS if I turned off the 1080p's? Also, do all the monitors have to run at the same refresh rate? Since two of the monitors are 60Hz, would it cap the 4K 240Hz monitor at 60Hz as well?  If the answer to any of the above is yes, would it be better if I ran only the 4K off the 4090 and ran the two 1080p's via the i9's integrated graphics (using the motherboard's two USB-C DisplayPort outputs)? Are there any downsides to doing it that way?   Question the second   Say I use the i9's integrated graphics to power the 1080p monitors as described above. Does dragging an application window from those monitors to the 4K monitor change which GPU it's running on? I feel like that wouldn't make sense but idk.   Question the third   Once I eventually get all three monitors working in whatever configuration is best, what do I need to do in order to make it so that the cursor and applications move seamlessly between screens? I know how to adjust display position and scaling in Windows. Is it just as easy as setting the display scaling on the 4K monitor to 200%?  Thank you for helping me live my multi-monitor dream/nightmare :)
